The astrolabe on the Clock Tower in Berne was likely used for both astronomical observations and as a decorative feature. Astrolabes were used by astronomers and navigators to determine the positions of celestial bodies and to make calculations related to time, distance, and direction. In a way, the astrolabe on the Clock Tower was a statement of Berne's intellectual and scientific achievements, as well as its pride in being a city with a long tradition of astronomy and astrology.

It is also important to note that in the late Middle Ages, scientific knowledge was deeply intertwined with religious and spiritual beliefs. The Clock Tower was built by the city's first inhabitants, who were closely connected to the local church. So the astrolabe, as well as the other mechanical features of the clock, may have been seen as a celebration of both scientific and religious knowledge. Overall, the astrolabe on the Clock Tower is a testament to the skill and ingenuity of the craftsmen who designed and built it, and to the importance of science and learning in Berne's cultural history.
